div.p: School is closed until further notice. Online learning will take place starting April 6, 2020. Please visit our COVID-19 Info Page for the latest information as well as information on how we are supporting our students (Food service, Chromebooks, Internet, Online Learning, Student Services)

span.a: You are currently on this page - COVID-19 Info Page

td.h3: Free School Meals | Chromebooks | Internet Access | Health Services | Online Learning | Student Services | Video Conferencing

strong.span: Public Health Madison Dane County is asking that we remind families, students, and community members that all school grounds are closed until further notice due to

p.span: . In addition to the school building, this includes all courts and playgrounds. People can still use community outdoor open spaces if they are alone or with members of their household as long as they keep 6ft of social distancing from others.

img.alt: Tips for physical distancing in parks

td.h2: Protecting Our Students and Community from Coronavirus

p.span: We continue to navigate through the rapidly changing situation with COVID-19.

First and foremost, Thank you for all your efforts, support and communication during this difficult time. I know it is hard at times to wrap our thoughts around what is happening and how fast everything changes.
As more information is presented on a daily basis, we want you to know we are committed to getting you this information as quickly as possible but also ensuring it is accurate as well.

With the latest recommendations in mind, all of our facilities will be closed to visitors beginning Thursday, March 18. If you have questions, please email your building secretary or principal. Please contact the district website for the updated information
. For now the best method of contact is email.
As per Governor Tony Ever’s directive, we are planning as if students will be out of school for an extended period of time.

We know these are tough times, and that having your kids get together with other kids brings a sense of comfort (and gives you a break too)! However, it’s extremely important that you and your family maintain physical distance from other people who live outside of your home. Do not host play dates, meet up at the park, or let your children hang out with their friends during the day, evening, or on the weekends.
Rachel Goldberg, MPH (pronouns: she/her/hers) | Health Education Specialist |
| 210 MLK Jr. Blvd, Rm. 507 Madison, WI 53703

Saludos familias,
¡Sabemos que estos son tiempos difíciles, y cuando sus hijos se reúnan con otros niños brinda una sensación de comodidad (y también le da un descanso)! Sin embargo, es extremadamente importante que usted y su familia mantengan la distancia física de otras personas que viven fuera de su hogar. No organice citas para jugar, no se reúnan en el parque ni permita que sus hijos vayan con sus amigos durante el día, la noche o los fines de semana.
Rachel Goldberg, MPH (pronouns: she/her/hers) | Health Education Specialist | rgoldberg@publichealthmdc.com
| 210 MLK Jr. Blvd, Rm. 507 Madison, WI 53703

img.alt: La Distancia Nos Hace Mas Fuertes
How to Prevent the Spread of Germs

span.b: What You Can Do and Our Cleaning Measures

p.span: The School District of Belleville has a routine cleaning regimen in place to help reduce the spread of germs and communicable disease. In addition to our regular cleaning and disinfection, we are increasing the cleaning of high-touch areas and hard and soft surface items throughout the day. We will follow all guidelines of the CDC and our local and state health departments.

div.span: We all play a role in helping reduce the spread of communicable disease. We are asking our students, staff and families to practice regular preventive actions

a.span: see flyer in English, Spanish, Hmong and Mandarin Chinese

li.span: Wash your hands regularly, for 20 seconds, using soap and hot water. Make sure to wash your fingertips. This is especially important after using the restroom, coughing or sneezing into your hands, and before preparing or consuming food.
Avoid coughing or sneezing into your hands or in the air. Always try to cough or sneeze into a tissue, and then throw the tissue away. If you don’t have a tissue, cough/sneeze into your arm.
As much as you can, avoid touching your eyes, mouth and nose.

If children are feeling sick, please keep them home from school. Families should have a plan in place for keeping your child home, picking up your child if they are sent home sick, and if schools are closed.
